metadata.case_name: Madhaorao Phalke v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: Appellant's ancestors accompanied Scindias to Gwalior from Maharashtra about 200 years ago and rendered military service in conquering Gwalior territory.
In recognition of service, appellant's ancestors granted fixed monthly amount of Rs. 21/8/- as Bachat balance, received by family for generations.
Right to receive amount recognised by Rulers of Gwalior in statutes, orders, rules or regulations including Kalambandis of 1912 and 1935.
Appellant describes himself as Ekkan; Ekkans were single volunteer horsemen bringing own horses and accoutrements, part of Peshwas Cavalry.
Other petitioners are Silledars, troopers bringing own horses and weapons, also known as Paigadars.
Expenses for horse maintenance deducted from total payable, leaving Rs. 21/8/- as Bachat.
Government of Madhya Bharat issued executive order on April 18, 1952, terminating payment to appellant.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Madhya Bharat High Court against State and Revenue Department for mandamus or direction to forbear from executive order.
Ten other similar petitions filed, all tried together by Full Bench (Shinde CJ, Dixit J, Newaskar J); held Kalambandis not law, petitions dismissed.
Certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) granted; appeal to Supreme Court.
On March 31, 1958, matter remanded to High Court for additional evidence on whether Kalambandis were statutes/regulations or administrative orders.
After remand, Abdul Hakim Khan J and Newaskar J held Kalambandis regulations having force of law; Krishnan J held contrary.
States of Gwalior, Indore, Malwa integrated in 1948; Act No. 1 of 1948 s.4 continued existing laws.
Notification Sept 19, 1950 by Commissioner Jagir Inams declared Bachat payments handled by his office.
Armies reorganised; hereditary pensions charged to Muafi department of Madhya Bharat Govt.
Impugned order clauses 1-4 continued payments to some; clause 5 stopped payments to Silledars/Ekkans not covered from May 1, 1952.
Sir Madhavrao set up Majlis Khas (1905), Majlis Quanun (1916), Majlis Am (1918); retained absolute powers.
First Kalambandi (1912) issued by Sir Madhavrao: 54 clauses, recognises hereditary rights, adoption, maintenance, mutation, restrictions on mortgage/execution.
Second Kalambandi (1935) by Council: 39 clauses, repeals 1912 regulations, similar provisions on succession, adoption, etc.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Kalambandis under which the appellant's right to receive Rs. 21/8/- per month by way of Bachat balance is guaranteed constitute an existing law within the meaning of Art. 372 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant's right to receive specified amount statutorily recognised by State of Gwalior; not open to respondent to extinguish by executive order.
Right to receive amount from month to month is property; cannot be divested without compensation under Art. 31.

respondent_arguments.text: Payment to appellant's ancestors and him was by way of emoluments for military service and did not constitute property.
Kalambandis on which appellant relies did not constitute an existing law under Art. 372; merely administrative orders.
Kalambandis not statutes as they did not satisfy forms and solemnities of Gwalior law-making machinery.

court_reasoning.text: In absolute monarchy like Gwalior, Ruler was source of all power; all orders had force of law, no distinction between executive and legislative.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between executive orders and legislative commands merely academic.

court_reasoning.text: Orders by absolute monarch amount to existing law under Art. 372 and Art. 366(10); no material difference between 'existing law' and 'law in force'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kalambandis saved under Art. 372 even if not technically quanun.

court_reasoning.text: Character of Kalambandis determined by content, not name or publication; detailed provisions on hereditary rights, adoption, mutation etc. impress statutory character.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1912 Kalambandi (54 clauses) and 1935 (39 clauses) like statutes/regulations.

court_reasoning.text: High Court finding of Abdul Hakim Khan J and Newaskar JJ correct that Kalambandis were regulations having force of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Impugned executive order invalid as cannot extinguish right under existing law.

holdings.text: Kalambandis constitute rules or regulations having force of law, hence existing law under Art. 372; executive order terminating payment invalid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Firman by Nizam had force of law; governs rights until annulled.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director of Endowments, Government of Hyderabad v. Akram Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Effective orders by Ruler of Indian State have force of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Edward Mills Co., Ltd., Beawar v. State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: No material difference between 'existing law' and 'law in force'.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Continuance of existing laws; definition; property; writs; appeal certificate.

statutes_cited.name: Act No. 1 of 1948 (Gwalior, Indore, Malwa Union)
statutes_cited.relevance: Continued existing laws of covenanting states.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of Indian law supports existing law.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; directed issuance of writ or order in favour of appellant as prayed, restraining respondents from giving effect to executive order terminating payments.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ in nature of mandamus or appropriate direction.

key_quotes.text: "The question of law which arises for our decision in this appeal is whether the Kalambandis under which the appellants right to receive Rs. 21/8/- per month by way of Bachat balance is guaranteed constitute an existing law within the meaning of Art. 372 of the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In dealing with the question as to whether the orders issued by such an absolute monarch amount to a law or regulation having the force of law, or whether they constitute merely administrative orders, it is important to bear in mind that the distinction between executive orders and legislative commands is likely to be merely academic."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reasoning on absolute monarchy and force of orders.

key_quotes.text: "Since we have answered this question in favour of the appellant we must allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that a proper writ or order should be issued in favour of the appellant as prayed for by him."
key_quotes.speaker: court
